Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: BCSP: Network level analysis of oxytocin regulation of naked mole rat and hippocampal neuron interactions.
Award.AbstractNarration: The goal of this project is to establish a research environment to investigate how the brain accomplishes the extraordinary task of orchestrating social behavior among members of a group. This work will take advantage of pre-existing differences in social behavior to test hypotheses about what systems in the brain are responsible for those differences. The naked mole rat (Heterocephalus Glaber) is a rodent that relies on social interaction and cooperative activity to survive in its harsh natural habitat. As a result, naked mole rats maintain the largest colony of any vertebrate animal, use a cooperative breeding system to raise young, and are capable of individual recognition of colony members. A preliminary examination, achieved through the development of novel technological tools to track behaviors, demonstrates that within each colony, there is variability in the amount of time animals spend engaging in social behavior. With the help of students supported by this award, we will use a social network analysis approach to identify animals with particularly high or low levels of social behavior, and measure whether brain expression of a candidate hormone, oxytocin, corresponds to these individual differences. We will also manipulate oxytocin levels in the brains of targeted naked mole rats to determine how this influences their place in the social network. Finally, the effect of oxytocin on neuronal interactions in the naked mole rat brain will be determined by using large-scale recordings of neuron activity. As the mole rat behavior and neuronal data are collected, they will be shared, in real time, through social media outlets to promote collaboration and provide unique educational opportunities for students at all educational levels. Teaching fellows, funded through this proposal will help to use these tools to develop new science curriculum for K-12 students in New York City public schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
African naked mole-rats have challenged what it means to be a land-dwelling mammal. Naked mole-rats live almost exclusively underground, have an extremely long lifespan, are highly resistant to cancer and pain, and can go long periods with little or no oxygen.  Perhaps the biggest challenge to what it means to be mammal is the naked mole-rat cooperative breeding lifestyle.  African naked mole-rats are eusocial; they have a queen and breeding male and as many as 300 non-reproductive colony workers who do not leave the colony nest when they reach adulthood. While common in insects, eusociality is very rare in mammals;  only 2 of the over 5000 recognized mammalian species have this trait: the naked mole-rat and the closely-related Damaraland mole-rat.

This NSF CAREER Award was designed to shed new light on how the mammalian brain functions to support such an unusual social organization.  To do this, we relied on a new approach for whole-colony animal movement tracking using Radio Frequency Identification (RFID). We developed the tools to collect the individual and collective movements of every member of our captive naked mole-rat colonies for weeks at a time.  \When the data were compiled, one pattern emerged very clearly: all members of the naked mole-rat colony spent the majority of each hour in the colony nest, no matter the time of day or what types of stimuli were provided in other parts of the housing environment.  We wondered whether the differences in air quality between the colony nest and other areas was important. Measurement of air quality in the nest showed that nest areas in captivity can reach high levels of carbon dioxide (CO2) from the breathing of a dense population of animals in a small space, rising to more than 60 times the levels in Earth’s atmosphere (2.5%).  When this level of CO2 was delivered elsewhere, animals left the nest and eventually moved the nest to location where CO2 was delivered. This attraction to CO2 adds to the growing list of mammal-defying properties of African Naked Mole-Rats.

We proposed that a hormone that is known for social behavior in other mammals, oxytocin, might be important to naked mole-rat social organization. Our initial analysis did not show individual differences in the receptor for oxytocin, which we interpreted to mean that all animals rely heavily on oxytocin for social behavior. We did, however, find another system, related to oxytocin, to work quite differently in the naked mole-rat. This system is GABA (gamma aminobutyric acid), which has an important role in balancing the activity of the mammalian brain.  In most mammals, GABA works by allowing chloride ions to enter neurons. This inhibits the activity of the neuron, creating a sedative effect.  The ability of GABA to repeatedly inhibit neurons improves during development, as mammals develop tools to clear the neurons of accumulated chloride. This is done primarily through a potassium (K+) -chloride (Cl-) cotransporter (KCC) which is positioned on the membrane of the neuron and moves ions across it. One form of KCC, KCC2 is suppressed in early development and, as a result, GABA is less able to inhibit neurons and may even excite them. We have found evidence that KCC2 in the naked mole-rat is suppressed well into adulthood. Our evidence suggests that this makes them more sensitive to the external environment and perhaps rely upon regular doses of CO2 to help keep the brain in balance. We observed that adult naked mole-rats show increased excitability and seizures in response to GABA-enhancing sedatives outside of the nest, but typical sedative responses inside the nest. Examination of the KCC2 gene in the naked mole-rat shows that a single point is switched in this species which makes the cotransporter less able to move to the neuron membrane.

Taken together, our results from this award extend the surprising features of naked mole-rat to include a brain that is dependent upon external CO2 levels to maintain inhibition through GABA. We propose that naked mole-rats have adapted to depend upon the high CO2 they might experience in the nest to help keep the brain balanced.  This adaptation may explain why naked mole-rats are rare among mammals in their lifelong return to the colony nest. Remarkably, we observe that the only other eusocial mammal, the Damaraland mole rat, is the only other mammal to have a change in the KCC2 gene in the exact same position.  Furthermore, a change in the equivalent position of the KCC2 gene in the human genome have been linked to neurodevelopmental disorders in humans.  These findings which have been generated by students in our lab ranging from high school, undergraduate, master’s and PhD levels, have been disseminated to the scientific community in a number of conference presentations and journal articles, and to the broader public sphere through television and web media.
